editorialDecl.p: Hyphens from printed version have been removed

Obvious printing errors have been corrected, but not if there is a possiblity that these could represent medieval ms. readings (for details of emendations see the introduction to G. Silgagi and T reuter, Wortkonkordanz zum Decretum Gratiani, Munich, 1989/90

Friedberg's use of quotation marks has been rationalised (single quotes [27 hex] for quotes within quotes) and completed as far as possible, as has his somewhat erratic use of square brackets to distinguish additions made by the Correctores Romani to the text. No attempt has been made to distinquish between opening and closing quotes

Some of the text has been enclosed between a minus and a plus sign to denote commentary. These include: page numbers; chapter, book, etc. divisions; square-bracketed additions by the CR; the word PALEA; the 13th century paragraph divisions (@. 1, etc.); titles

refsDecl.p: T T = text, i.e. the piece of canon law being quoted
P = palea: 1 for yes, 0 for no
2 = the number of the major division
3 = the number of the Quaestio, in the case of the Causae
